description: Borrowed from Latin interruptus, from interrumpere (“to break apart, break to pieces, break off, interrupt”), from inter (“between”) + rumpere (“to break”).

entries.meaning: (computing, electronics) An event that causes a computer or other device to temporarily cease what it was doing and attend to a condition.
examples: The interrupt caused the packet handler routine to run.

verbs.description: interrupt (third-person singular simple present interrupts, present participle interrupting, simple past and past participle interrupted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To disturb or halt (an ongoing process or action, or the person performing it) by interfering suddenly.
examples: A maverick politician repeatedly interrupted the debate by shouting.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To divide; to separate; to break the monotony of.
examples: The evenness of the road was not interrupted by a single hill.

entries.meaning: (transitive, computing) To assert to (a computer) that an exceptional condition must be handled.
examples: The packet receiver circuit interrupted the microprocessor.
